references: Root, T. 1988. Atlas of wintering North American birds:An analysis of Christmas Bird Count data. University of Chicago Press. 336 pp.
Taylor, J. P., and R. E. Kirby. 1990. Experimental dispersal of wintering snow and Ross' geese. Wildl. Soc. Bull. 18:312-319.
Bartlett, D. 1975. The flight of the snow geese. 189 pp.
Avise, J. C., et al. 1992. Matriarchal population genetic structure in an avian species with female natal philopatry. Evolution 46:1084-1096.
American Ornithologists' Union (AOU). 1983. Check-list of North American Birds, 6th edition. Allen Press, Inc., Lawrence, Kansas. 877 pp.
Pratt, H.D., P.L. Bruner, and D.G. Berrett. 1987. A field guide to the birds of Hawaii and the tropical Pacific. Princeton University Press, Princeton, New Jersey. 409 pp. + 45 plates.
Giroux, J.-F., and J. Bedard. 1988. Use of bulrush marshes by greater snow geese during staging. J. Wildl. Manage. 52:415-420.
Ratcliffe, L., R. F. Rockwell, and F. Cooke. 1988. Recruitment and maternal age in lesser snow geese CHEN CAERULESCENS CAERULESCENS. J. Anim. Ecol. 57:553-563.
Cooke, F., D. T. Parkin, and R. F. Rockwell. 1988. Evidence of former allopatry of the two color phases of lesser snow geese (CHEN CAERULSCENS CAERULESCENS). Auk 105:467-479.
Johnson, S.R., and D.R. Herter. 1989. The birds of the Beaufort Sea. BP Exploration (Alaska) Inc., Anchorage, Alaska. 372 pp.
Kortright, F.H. 1967. The ducks, geese, and swans of North America. The Stackpole Company, Harrisburg, PA, and Wildlife Management Institute, Washington, D.C. 476 pp.
U.S. Fish & Wildl. Serv. 1988. SEIS 88. Final supplemental environmental impact statement:issuance of annual regulations permitting the sport hunting of migratory birds. x + 340 pp.
Cogswell, H.L. 1977. Water birds of California. Univ. California Press, Berkeley. 399 pp.
Godfrey, W.E. 1966. The birds of Canada. National Museums of Canada. Ottawa. 428 pp.
Soper, J. D. 1942. Life history of the blue goose. Proc. Boston Soc. Nat. Hist 42:121-225.
Cooch, E. G., et al. 1989. Long-term decline in fecundity in a snow goose population:evidence for density dependence? J. Anim. Ecol. 58:711-726.
Livezey, B. C. 1986. A phylogenetic analysis of recent Anseriform genera using morphological characters. Auk 103:737-754.
Jackson, S. L., D. S. Hik, and R. F. Rockwell. 1988. The influence of nesting habitat on reproductive success of the lesser snow goose. Can. J. Zool. 66:1699-1703.
McLandress, M. R. 1983. Temporal changes in habitat selection and nest spacing in a colony of Ross' and lesser snow geese. Auk 100:335-343.
Terres, J.K. 1980. The Audubon Society encyclopedia of North American birds. Alfred A. Knopf, New York.
Gauthier, G., J.-F. Giroux, and J. Bedard. 1992. Dynamics of fat and protein reserves during winter and spring migration in greater snow geese. Can. J. Zool. 70:2077-2087.
habitat_description:
The Snow Goose (Chen caerulescens) breeds in Alaska and Canada and winters at various locations in the conterminous U.S.  Their southwestern range includes Nevada where they are “common fall/spring migrant visitants”, especially at Stillwater and Carson Lake areas of Churchill Co. but few winter in southern part of the state.   They are abundant migrants in extreme eastern Colorado and winter residents in southeast Colorado.  White morphs are abundant fall and spring migrants and winter residents in the Arkansas River valley but uncommon elsewhere. The blue morph is uncommon to common during spring and fall migration in the Arkansas River valley, rare elsewhere. They are very Rare winter resident on eastern plains.  They are more common east of the Rockies where they are generally associated with large marsh and wetland habitats. During migration between winter and summer habitat, many snow geese pass through Utah, congregating in such areas as Gunnison Bend in Millard Co.  They are found in the Rockies.

Suitable winter habitat includes wetlands and standing water as well as grassy areas for foraging:  coastal freshwater and brackish marshes, fields of waste potatoes (Solanum tuberosum), inland freshwater marshes, impoundments, marine inlets, saltwater cordgrass, salt grass (Disticilis spicata) marsh, salt-meadow grass, upland coastal bluestem prairie, rice (Oryza sativa) fields, soybean fields (Glycine max), rye (Secale cereale), wheat,marine bays, wet prairies, extensive sandbars, wet grasslands, pastures, tidal marshes of deltas dominated by American bulrush and flooded agricultural fields (Hill & Frederick 1997, BNA #514).   They are attracted to freshly burned ground because once above ground vegetation is removed, tubers and roots are easy foraging.  N. Tarr, 6March2013.
